title: SPARQL-to-SQL on Internet of Things Databases and Streams

author: Eugene Siow Boon Lin, School of Electronics and Computer Science, University of Southampton

segmentation: I'm Eugene cell from the University of Southampton.

This works with tenacity, Rupani, said Wendy Hall's title sparkle to SQL and Internet of Things devices and streams, so I got here to Kobe on Tuesday and I had a half a day before the conference so I decided to climb the highest mountain in Kobe.
So this is a picture of the summit of Mount Rokko, which is 931 meters, and that's the picture that I took.
It's gotta be really beautiful view of the city an it's me the selfie with 91 meters.
So what happened was that usually I am hobbies, mountain tracking mountain tracker.
So I like to climb mountains everywhere.
Usually I use my GPS offline Maps.
But it didn't work this time, so.
I was quite worried because when I was coming down all the signs were in hiragana and couldn't read them.
So what happened was Fortunately I had an offline map on my phone, which is, well.
It's a very rough map, but I think what it shows is that sometimes there's poor connectivity or it costs £3.00 per MB for data and you might not want to use that.
So what happen?
Is that the current state of the Internet of Things we have sensor data from multiple sources.
It's kind of in production data silos, so siloed data huge dependency on the cloud for good or for bad an there's limited interoperability of these apps which work for the Internet of Things.
So my idea is basically link data on lightweight computers bridging what's in the cloud and what's on the ground from the sensor.
Yes.
So for interoperability, Link data UI ontologies help because they establish common data structures and references and able to reach metadata an integrates with linked open data, so it's great.
And then we have lightweight computers so lightweight computers can be for example Raspberry Pis or or Intel's Atom.
You have sensors on the ground you have this devices which are somewhere in between the cloud and the ground.
Some people like to call it for some people like the court do.
And then you have applications which can run on these devices and then you have the cloud and you have a larger scale kind of applications.
So some of the challenges we know performance is a challenge for web scale data.
So especially when you have resource constrained devices could could be could be a bigger challenge.
So these are the specs of generally a Raspberry Pi.
An we have both historical and streaming data, so we need to think of both of these.
So what I did was to optimize for lightweight computers.
I looked at the shape of time series data in the IO T. What I did was we looked at do it IO which is sort of like a Twitter for IoT devices.
So people publish their sensor data.
I looked at the schema of 20 K unique devices and about 99.5% is flat, which I mean it's not something unexpected.
Very little of that data is actually complex schema and the average width was four, so it's actually pretty wide.
And yeah, you do have these most common columns at most column fields are generally time stem with temperature, humidity, pressure, and light.
So time series data looks.
Something like this when model with things with some ontologies or wrestling data.
It kind of looks like that when you look at it in triples.
And of these quite a big portion of it is observation metadata which is basically ID's.
You have a bit of.
Sensor meta data which describes the sensor itself and you have these as the actual observation data.
The actual values.
So why not we put the?
Observation data in tables and the metadata in.
Mapping in memory.
So that's the general idea of our engine.
So you have tables, you have the mapping and you have bindings between the the mapping and the table.
And then when you get a sequel, Sparkle Query coming in.
Basically what I do is break into the algebra so it's a tree and you have the BGP at the base.
You have certain operators operating above.
Take the BGP executed or executed on the mapping and you get a result set which comes out.
Something like that and then with this results.
It forms.
You go up the tree and it becomes.
A SQL query.
So it's a very simple idea, actually.

So we have a bigger query with two unions and some filters.
Look something like that in algebra.
You do the same thing.
Resolve the GPS.
And.
Then translates to SQL.
So the.
Magic is kind of in the mappings which are stored in memory.
These are generally metadata which.
It's not repeated like the Rose in the columns.

Ann, you have bindings here, but when you get a query so you have this be GPS in the query and basically they form simple select star statement in sparkle and the mappings generally RDF so you can use any in memory engine.
Jena Sesame implemented general sesame.
In Java interface you can implement any engine and just execute it on the mappings to get a result set back and this forms your variable mappings.
So this kind of mappings written in RDF.
There are two RML compatible means.
It can be translated to and from RML.
The difference is that they are generally so so that I can just execute the select star query on it.
And it supports collapsing notes, which are generally will not be projected or we think will not be projected.
So for example, all the IDE notes you generally don't need them for.
Your applications, so we have created.
Something called 4 notes F notes which.
Provide a promise to materialize or two to produce these ID columns if they're projected, so if they're not projected, you don't produce them, and you can generally collapse them.
OK, so for streams it's similar.
The engine is exactly the same, it's just that we consider the translation to SQL to EPL, which is event processing language of Esper instead.
It's just like you consider the different SQL dialects.
So basically it's the process of registering the query, translating it, receiving the stream data, and receiving the results.
So this is a. Sparkle to stream Query, which is generally a sea sparkle kind of syntax.
An translate it to EPL looks something like this.

Elevation with benchmarks.
So we use the streaming benchmark as our bench.
2000 stations, about 10, about 100 to 200 K triples, and these are of wind rainfall.
Things like that and some queries.
Another benchmark with smart home benchmark, so it's three months of smart home data and about 30 K triples.

State of the art.

So much less verbals and much smaller across the various datasets.

Three times.
A two times improvement, at least for the queries for query for you, get a huge improvement because it's basically trying to join two subgraphs.

You have about the same performance on query for an.

I think it's about 200 MB as a yeah.

Good to know that you're working in the area.
